content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects millions of Americans, including children, and is the most common chronic respiratory disease in children. The prevalence of pediatric asthma has significantly increased over the years. The prevalence of asthma is higher in preschool children, with a 160 percent increase. It is also more common in women than in men, with 5.6 percent of women and 5.1 percent of men affected. Asthma is more prevalent in low-income families, with 79.2 out of 1,000 individuals under 45 in families earning less than $10,000 affected, compared to 53.6 out of 1,000 in families earning $20,000 to $35,000. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma attacks. During 1993-1995, African Americans had an average of 38.5 asthma deaths per million individuals, compared to 15.1 deaths for Caucasians. Asthma costs the US over $12 billion annually, with rising prevalence leading to higher future costs. African Americans are five times more likely to seek asthma care in emergency rooms. The asthma death rate is four times higher in African American children and two times higher overall. Exercise can improve the physical and psychological well-being of children, including boosting self-esteem and helping manage asthma. It also promotes lifelong habits of physical activity, enhancing quality and length of life. SEC. 3. GRANTS FOR PROJECTS FOR ASTHMA-RELATED ACTIVITIES FOR LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants for projects in low-income communities for screenings, education, and workshops on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants for projects in low-income communities for screenings, education, and workshops on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems. Nurses, school counselors, athletic coaches, and other individuals in supervisory roles of children in these communities will ensure comprehensive screenings and referrals in traditional medical settings like hospitals and nontraditional settings such as nurseries and schools. The Secretary of Health and Human Services provides grants for projects in low-income communities for screenings, education, and workshops on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems. Services include nurseries, schools, community centers, public housing units, volunteer organizations, convenience stores, and governmental offices offering cash assistance for low-income individuals. Information and education on asthma and allergies are provided in various settings. The information and education provided in various settings includes details on symptoms, prevention, and management of conditions like asthma and respiratory problems. It is tailored to the language and cultural context of the intended individuals. The importance of providing information and education on asthma management, including medication options and the need for asthmatic children to engage in physical activities, in traditional and nontraditional settings. The Secretary will evaluate projects under subsection (a) to determine the impact on children receiving screenings and referrals, the effectiveness in preventing and managing asthma and related respiratory problems, and the efficacy of information and education materials used. The grant recipient must be a community-based organization serving the low-income community where the project will take place or demonstrate significant involvement from such an organization. The Secretary may award grants for projects focused on providing information and education. The Secretary may make a grant under subsection (a) only if an application is submitted in the required form and contains necessary information. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. The National Media Campaign will provide asthma-related information. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign to provide information on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems, with a focus on children. The campaign must include information on prevention and management of these conditions. The national media campaign provides information on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems, focusing on children. It includes details on prevention, management, screenings, referrals, and treatment in the community, tailored to the language and cultural context of the target audience. Authorization of Appropriations: $600,000 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. SEC. 5. Tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services under SEC. 45D of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credit of 10% for providing qualified pest control and climate control services without charge. Qualified pest control and climate control services provided without charge in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties with at least 75% of occupants below 200% of the poverty line are eligible for a 10% tax credit, subject to verification by the Secretary. The tax credit for qualified pest control and climate control services in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties with low-income occupants is subject to verification by the Secretary. Pest control and climate control services include eliminating pests and improving ventilation and temperature control. Amendments to the tax code are made to reflect these changes. Amendments to the tax code include adding a new paragraph for taxpayers providing pest control or climate control services, determining the donation credit under section 45D. Subsection (d) of the tax code is also amended to address carryback and carryforward of unused credits. The tax code is amended to prevent the carryback of the section 45D credit before January 1, 2000. The tax code is amended to allow a credit for donations of pest control and climate control services, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Additionally, there is a provision for research on the relationship between air pollutants and asthma-related problems. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA Administrator, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory issues. Priority will be given to clinical research for individuals affected by these conditions. The research will prioritize clinical evaluations for individuals residing in low-income communities to study the connection between air pollutants and respiratory health issues like asthma and allergies. SEC. 7. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will identify federal asthma-related programs, develop a federal response plan with input from various organizations, and submit recommendations to Congress for improving coordination of federal asthma activities within 12 months of this Act's enactment. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will have a representative on the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee. $5,000,000 from NIH funds will be allocated to the program for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. Funds allocated under this subsection are in addition to other appropriations for the National Asthma Education Prevention Program. SEC. 8. COMPILATION OF DATA BY CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management quality through telephone surveys and health care facility specific surveillance. They compile and annually publish this data. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, compiles and annually publishes data on the prevalence of children suffering from asthma in each State and the childhood mortality rate associated with asthma nationally and in each State.
